## Slide 1: What is Secondary Traumatic Stress (STS)? {.small}

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%" style="font-size: 0.70em; line-height: 1.3;"}

- STS mimics PTSD, resulting from indirect exposure to others' trauma [@figley1995compassion; @baird2006vicarious]  
- Common in service professions:  
  - Therapists  
  - First responders  
  - Teachers  
- Symptoms include:  
  - Intrusion  
  - Avoidance  
  - Arousal [@bride2004development]  
- STS affects mental, physical and emotional health

:::

::: {.column width="40%" style="text-align:center;"}

## Slide 2: STS and Teachers

::: {.columns style="display: flex; align-items: flex-start;"}

::: {.column style="flex: 0 0 60%;"}

- Teachers are exposed to trauma:  
  - **Directly:** school violence, threats, student aggression  
  - **Indirectly:** student trauma from abuse, poverty, neglect [@inabnett2023secondary]

- High-needs / Title I schools ‚Üí higher risk of STS 

- Teacher well-being is linked to stress and school conditions [@kidger2016teachers]

:::

## Slide 3: STS, Burnout, and Attrition

:::{.columns}
::: {.column width="70%"}
<div style="font-size: 0.8em;">

- Chronic stress leads to burnout ‚Üí emotional, mental, and physical toll [@baker2021experience]  
- Burnout dimensions: emotional exhaustion, cynicism, inefficacy [@chang2009appraisal]  
- Burnout types:  
  - Personal  
  - Work-related  
  - Student-related [@de2017burnout]  
- Burnout contributes to teacher attrition [@hilton2021predicting]  

</div>
:::

## Slide 4: STS Measurement & Relevance 

:::{.columns}
::: {.column width="55%"}
<div style="font-size: 0.7em;">
- STS measured by Secondary Traumatic Stress Scale (STSS):  
  17 items across intrusion, avoidance, arousal subscales  

- Mentors are uniquely positioned to recognize and respond to STS in residents ‚Äî a key factor in early career persistence  

- Taking the STSS helps build self-awareness around how stress may be affecting you personally  

- Your reflection can inform how you support residents ‚Äî and how you model healthy coping  

</div>

## Slide 5: STSS Self-Assessment

### Secondary Traumatic Stress Scale (STSS)

<div style="font-size: 0.60em; line-height: 1.2;">

üß† **Purpose:**  
To reflect on your own experiences with stress and emotional impact related to supporting students who have experienced trauma.

---

### ‚úçÔ∏è Instructions:
- Please complete the **17-item STSS** using your honest, personal responses.
- Rate how frequently you've experienced each item **in the past week**, using the scale provided.
- There are no right or wrong answers ‚Äî this is **not a test** or evaluation.
- You will **not be asked to share your score**. This is for your own reflection.

---

### üõë Before You Begin:
- Take a breath. This may bring up emotions ‚Äî that‚Äôs normal.
- You are welcome to opt out at any time.

‚è±Ô∏è **You‚Äôll have about 5‚Äì7 minutes to complete it.**

</div>


## Slide 6: STSS Self-Reflection

### Interpreting Your STSS Score

<div style="font-size: 0.7em;">

üß† **This is a personal tool for reflection, not evaluation.**  
Your score is for *you* ‚Äî to consider how stress may be showing up in your work.

---

### üí¨ Reflection Prompts:

- What stood out to you about your score?
- Were any subscale areas (intrusion, avoidance, arousal) more elevated than others?
- How might stress show up *differently* for your student teacher resident?
- How do you typically respond when you're under significant stress at work?
- What support would have helped *you* when you were new to teaching?

---

üìù *Take 2‚Äì3 minutes to jot down your thoughts before we continue.*

</div>



## Slide 7: Visualizing Risk

### Attrition Probability and Total Score

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.width=9.5, fig.height=5.5, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(readr)

# Load your data
sts_data <- read_csv("sts_data.csv")

# Define prediction function
pred_prob <- function(x, intercept, slope) {
  log_odds <- intercept + slope * x
  1 / (1 + exp(-log_odds))
}

# Model coefficients for STSS Total Score
beta0_total <- -2.1175
beta1_total <-  0.0317

# Generate sequence and predictions for STSS Total Score
stss_seq <- seq(min(sts_data$stss_total_score, na.rm = TRUE),
                max(sts_data$stss_total_score, na.rm = TRUE), length.out = 100)

df_total <- data.frame(
  score = stss_seq,
  probability = pred_prob(stss_seq, beta0_total, beta1_total),
  model = "STSS Total Score"
)

# Define shaded zones for score ranges (0‚Äì85)
zones <- data.frame(
  xmin = c(0, 29, 57),
  xmax = c(28, 56, 85),
  fill = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)
zones$fill <- factor(zones$fill, levels = c("Low", "Medium", "High"))

# Plot STSS Total Score with shaded zones
ggplot() +
  # Background score range shading
  geom_rect(data = zones, aes(xmin = xmin, xmax = xmax, ymin = 0, ymax = 1, fill = fill),
            alpha = 0.15, inherit.aes = FALSE) +
  
  # Predicted probability line
  geom_line(data = df_total, aes(x = score, y = probability, color = model), linewidth = 1.2) +
  
  # Customize legend and theme
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Low" = "lightgreen", "Medium" = "khaki", "High" = "lightcoral")) +
  labs(
    x = "STSS Total Score",
    y = "Predicted Probability of Attrition",
    title = "Predicted Probability of Attrition by STSS Total Score",
    color = NULL,
    fill = "Score Range"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(size = 14),
    legend.position = "right"
  )


```
<div style="font-size: 0.65em; margin-top: 1em;">

- Total STSS reflects overall stress impact ‚Äî e.g., resident expresses feeling overwhelmed or doubts their fit for the profession.

</div>

## Slide 8: Visualizing Risk

### Attrition Probability and Intrusion Score

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.width=9.5, fig.height=5.5, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)

# Prediction function
pred_prob <- function(x, intercept, slope) {
  log_odds <- intercept + slope * x
  1 / (1 + exp(-log_odds))
}

# Coefficients for Intrusion
beta0_intrusion <- -2.1044
beta1_intrusion <- 0.1091

# Prediction data
intrusion_seq <- seq(0, 25, length.out = 100)
df_intrusion <- data.frame(
  score = intrusion_seq,
  probability = pred_prob(intrusion_seq, beta0_intrusion, beta1_intrusion)
)

# Shaded zones
zones_intrusion <- data.frame(
  xmin = c(0, 9, 18),
  xmax = c(8, 17, 25),
  fill = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)

# Plot
p_intrusion <- ggplot() +
  geom_rect(data = zones_intrusion, aes(xmin = xmin, xmax = xmax, ymin = 0, ymax = 1, fill = fill),
            alpha = 0.15) +
  geom_line(data = df_intrusion, aes(x = score, y = probability), color = "#1f77b4", linewidth = 1.2) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Low" = "lightgreen", "Medium" = "khaki", "High" = "lightcoral")) +
  labs(
    x = "Intrusion Score",
    y = "Predicted Probability of Attrition",
    title = "Attrition Risk by Intrusion Score",
    fill = "Score Range"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(text = element_text(size = 14))

print(p_intrusion)


```

<div style="font-size: 0.65em; margin-top: 1em;">
 
- Intrusion can present as re-living student trauma ‚Äî e.g., resident repeatedly brings up distressing student stories and reports difficulty "shaking it off."

</div>

## Slide 11: Implications for Mentors

### What This Means for You as a Mentor

- Some residents may be showing signs of STS without realizing it.  
- Higher stress doesn‚Äôt just affect well-being ‚Äî it predicts intent to leave.  
- Early recognition and open, nonjudgmental conversations can be protective.  
- You‚Äôre in a key position to model and support stress management strategies.

## Slide 12: Gallery Walk Instructions

### How to Participate

<ul style="font-size: 0.8em; padding-left: 1.2rem;">
  <li>Form a group of 2‚Äì3 people to move through the stations with.</li>
  <li>Rotate through the stations around the room; each has a different question.</li>
  <li>Spend about 2.5 to 3 minutes at each station reflecting and writing your group‚Äôs thoughts.</li>
  <li>Write your responses on the sticky notes and place them on the chart paper.</li>
  <li>Think about how the questions relate to your role as a mentor.</li>
  <li>Keep an eye on the time to ensure everyone visits all stations.</li>
  <li>After the rotations, be ready to share 1‚Äì2 key insights or strategies from your group during the full-group discussion.</li>
</ul>
